div.head: 3336. Robert Southey to John Rickman, [c. 23 July 1819]
div.p:
MS: Huntington Library, RS 372. ALS; 2p.
Unpublished.
Dating note: Dating from content; the reference to Davison’s marriage and honeymoon journey.

I forgot to say that I attended to your remarks upon the Preface & conclusion as far as I could. – But I could find no means of altering the expression fit audience, – tho I felt as you did respecting upon transferring it from a poem to an historical composition. History of Brazil, 3 vols (London, 1810–1819), III, p. 879: ‘fit audience however I know that it will find’. The phrase ‘fit audience’ echoes John Milton (1608–1674; DNB), Paradise Lost (1667), Book 7, line 31. The Pernambucan MS. for which Koster is thanked relates to 1710, – not to the recent rebellion. History of Brazil, 3 vols (London, 1810–1819), III, p. vi. Koster had given Southey a transcription of ‘Guerra Civil ou Sedissoens de Pernambuco Exemplo Memoravel aos vindouros 1710’, no. 3840 in the sale catalogue of Southey’s library. This manuscript dealt with the Mascate War, or ‘War of the Peddlers’, in Pernambuco in 1710–1711, covered in History of Brazil (London, 1810–1819), III, pp. 85–107; not the Pernambuco insurrection of 1817.

Davison (de Pauperibus) having been rewarded for his good works in that pamphlett & in the QR by a good living, has taken a wife, & is on his way to the Lakes.John Davison (1777–1834; DNB), clergyman and author of Considerations on the Poor Laws (1817). He had been made Rector of Washington, Co. Durham, in 1818 and married Mary Thorp (dates unknown), daughter of Robert Thorp (dates unknown), a lawyer in Alnwick, on 20 July 1819. He has introduced himself by letter, & will be at Keswick on Monday next.
I shall be ready to start upon receiving your summons, – & till it arrives must make the best use of my time.
